Variation Example: A louse that has been found on a princess (king) is fat tened to an enormous size (becomes as big as a sheep, calf, ox) & slaughtered. The king (princess, queen) displays the skin in public (has a dress, shoes, gloves made from it; has a chair or drum covered with it; has the louse’s meat pre pared) & announces, that whoever guesses the kind of animal the skin belongs to will receive half of the kingdom & also the princess in marriage. A (disguised) monster (real or false beggar, shepherd, animal, dis-guised robber, devil, cannibal ogre), who learns the secret by trickery, guesses correctly & wins the princess. In some variants the princess is rescued from the monster’s power. She escapes with a magic flight (with the assistance of super natural or skillful helpers).

Classifications: The Penniless Bridegroom Pretends to Wealth
Variation Example: A penniless suitor pretends to be wealthy by boasting & manages to marry the daughter of a rich man. This tale exists chiefly in five different forms: (1) A rich man wants to marry his daughter only to a rich man. A poor suitor (sometimes two) pretends to be rich by disguising him self & telling lies to the girl’s father. When the father is ready to marry him to his daughter the suitor burns a wooden tower & pre tends that all his riches have vanished in the fire. Sometimes the bride exposes him by visiting him incognito in his home. (2) After the marriage the bridegroom takes his bride to show her his land. He puts on soiled (patched) clothes. When she looks at the land he points to a patch in his jacket (trousers) saying, “This patch is mine!” (3) An uncle wants a wife for his nephew. He gives the boy a coin & food to hold while he makes the arrangement. He tells the girl’s father that his nephew has money in his hand & plenty to eat. So he wins the girl. (4) When a servant boasts that his house has 150 lights & a goat-pen, his master marries his daughter to him. Arriving at his home they realize that the lights are the stars shining through the cracks in the roof & one goat is tied to a tree. (5) A suitor touches his whiskers saying, “All of these are mine!”, whereupon the girl thinks he is referring to the fields & livestock which they are riding past.

A princess is offered to any man who can bring a glass containing all kinds of water, a bouquet of all the flowers, & nuts of ay, ay, ay! A suitor brings seawater, a beehive, & hazel nuts with thorns so that the king cries, “Ay, ay, ay!”

A merchant abducts another man’s wife (builds an underground passage to her home). Her sons & the husband search for her. After a series of ad ventures they find her. The abductor is punished (escapes).

A mar ried (unmarried) man falls in love with a beautiful woman (prin cess), who makes signs or gives gifts to him. His wife (another helper) tells him that the signs show where the beautiful woman lives. He arranges to meet her but arrives too early & falls asleep. She does not wake him but leaves a token. A later meeting is successful. The adulterous couple is caught & taken to prison. The man sends word to his wife (sister, servant, old woman). She visits him in prison & changes clothing with the beautiful woman (husband), who goes out of the prison, leaving the married couple (two women) behind. The prisoners are set free because there is now no evidence of a crime.

A prince (gardener, orphan) falls in love with the image of a beautiful woman & goes to seek her. He is secretly admitted to her room, & the two of them plan to elope together. However, the prince falls asleep & misses their appointment. Another man comes & runs away with the beautiful woman. She escapes from her abductor and, disguised as a man, finds employment. She relates her life story & through this the villain is discovered. He is put to death & the beautiful woman mar ries the prince.

A hermit wants to prove the truth of the following verse of the Bible (Matthew 7,7), “He that asks shall receive; he that searches shall find; he that knocks shall be admitted.” He asks to marry the ruler’s daughter, & his demand is accept ed on the condition that he will fulfill a difficult task. He returns to his cell where he meets the devil (imprisoned). He lures the devil into a water jug (glass, bottle), forces him to give him the requisite objects (jewel, a lost mug, key to hell, pearls, gold), & hands them over to the ruler. Then he lures the devil back into captivity (jug, glass, bottle). He tells the ruler about his intention & renounces the princess (marries her).

A greedy king proclaims a competition to choose the best suitor for his daughter. Three kings’ sons apply & are told to bake pancakes. The first tosses a pancake in the air, where it turns over three times before he catches it in the pan. The second tosses it up the chimney & runs outside to catch it. The third lets the pancake cook until it becomes brown, turns it over, & cooks the other side. He is declared to be the best suitor.

The nobleman Federigo Alberighi loves a woman, Monna Giovanna, who does not return his love. He spends all his wealth to woo her until only his falcon is left, which one of the best of its kind. When the lady’s sick son wants the falcon she goes to ask for it. In order to gain her favor, Federigo, not owning anything anymore, serves her unwittingly his precious falcon to eat. When she makes her request it is too late. Nevertheless she is impressed by his gener-ous attitude, changes her mind, & chooses him as her husband.

Classifications: The Princess Confined in the Mound
Variation Example: Because of her faithfulness to her betrothed (separ-a tion of the lovers by a quarrel or a war), a princess (along with her maid servant, sister) is confined by her father in an underground prison (cave, hollow hill, cellar, tower). After many (seven) years she escapes & enters service in the king’s (father of her lover) castle (without being recognized). She finds her lover about to marry another (witch, pregnant woman). (She works as lady’s maid for the prince’s new bride.) In order to conceal the pregnancy (because of the hideousness or sickness of the bride) the heroine is asked to take her place on wedding day. On the way to the church she talks to her horse, to the bridge, & to the church-door, & thus reminds the prince of his first love. After the wedding he gives her different objects or she loses things which the second bride had given to her (glove, muffler, necklace, ring, belt). The prince picks everything up. When in the evening the prince tests his wife’s identity by demanding that she repeat their conversation on the way to church she can not recall it without consulting the maidservant. When he demands to see the necklace (when he asks for the objects he had collected), the truth comes to light. He sends the second woman away & marries his faithful princess.

A poor girl (neighbor’s girl) is determined to marry a prince, who thinks this is an absurd idea. In vain he tries to make her understand that her plans are senseless. When he is about to marry a bride in accordance with his rank, the poor girl takes the place of his new bride in the marriage bed. The prince discovers the substitution (by the ornaments given to her or by a stone indicating chastity), but never theless he accepts the poor scorned girl as his wife. In the oldest variant from the northern area, a goose-girl declares to a prince that she intends to marry him even if he refuses. When the prince finds a bride of his own rank, the goose-girl warns her about a stone which will reveal her past sexual experiences. The bride asks the goose-girl to substitute for her during the wedding night. Never-theless the stone reveals the truth about the bride’s lost virginity & the prince finally accepts the goose-girl as his true bride. In the southern variants, a neighbor’s daughter believes (because of a prophecy) that she will marry a bey (shah, prince). When he learns about her idea he mocks her. When he marries a woman of his own rank the neighbor’s daughter is asked to substitute for the bride on the wedding night, because the bride had run away (was ugly or was not a virgin). Through special signs he discovers the de cep tion & finally accepts the neighbor’s daughter as his legal wife.

A princess who looks into a forbidden chamber sees a man’s picture & falls in love. A magician in bird form brings the princess at night to her lover. Once they stay too late. The sun sees them, so that the magician bursts & dies. The girl, left alone, becomes a servant in the palace, where she is threatened by a cannibal princess. She escapes through a narrow window & goes down a well which leads her to the underworld where she meets the chief of devils boiling the brains of the ogress princess. The heroine turns the pot upside down & returns to the well. The ogress is now normal. As a reward for her good deed the heroine is sent to her lover’s house, where she arrives just as he is about to marry another. He recognizes the princess & marries her.

Classifications: The Princess Who Goes to Seek Trouble
Variation Example: She loses her way in the forest, hides in a tree. A hunter camps under the tree. His dogs reveal the princess’s hiding place, & she is forced to come down. The hunter sleeps by her side, holding her plaits tightly in his hands. By cutting off her hair, the princess, unnoticed, makes her escape. In Russian variants the hunter pretends to be a sick girl. By ordering the young women to assemble, he recognizes the one who passed the night with him & marries her.

A woman goes to a king’s garden (underworld) & sees the queen meet a black lover (beggar, cripple). She denounces the queen & even tually marries the king. Or a friend of the king (another person) follows her & sees everything. On the order of her lover, the queen murders her husband. When she returns to her lover, he spurns her, saying that she will also murder him when she is tired of him.

A brother is married to an evil jealous wife who slanders his sister (accuses her of illicit sexual behav-ior) & expels her into the woods. Thanks to the advice of an ogress (water spirit, bird, giant woman) whom she meets there, the sister survives, proves her innocence, & marries a prince.

Classifications: The King Discovers his Unknown Son
Variation Example: A king (in disguise, unrecognized) leaves a token (ring) with a woman (widow) with whom he has passed the night. If she gives birth to a son she is to give him the token. The boy, mistreated because he is a bastard, goes to search for his unknown father. He becomes a baker & has a liai son with a noble girl. The king (his father) orders his execution. Just before the execution the token is discovered & the son is recognized as the son of the king. The king marries the boy’s mother.

A woman (princess, the youngest of three daughters) falls in love with a king (prince) whom she knows only from hearsay. She writes to him (has a letter or message sent by her father). But the king scorns & rejects her. (When she tells him that she weeps for him, he sends her a handkerchief; when she tells him that she intends to hang herself, he sends her a rope; when she threatens to commit suicide, he sends her a knife or dagger.) She takes revenge by humiliating him. She arranges to become one of his slaves. After he falls in love with her, she proves who she is by showing him the objects he had given to her. They are reconciled & marry.
A king promises his son to whatever woman can find her way through the 1000 rooms in his palace. A poor but clever girl succeeds by unwinding a spool of thread.

This type combines various introductory episodes with a common main part. Introductions: (1) A king looks for a wife and/or meets a clever girl by chance . (2) The father of the girl finds a golden mortar in a field and, against the advice of his clever daughter, takes it to the king who demands the pestle as well. (3) A quarrel between a farmer & a nobleman in court is settled by giving both riddles to be solved. The daughter of the farmer gives the right answers. (4) A king finds a girl in a house. When he asks her about her relatives she answers with wit & cleverness. Main part: The clever girl has to perform various tasks set by the king: she must come to the king neither naked nor clad, neither by horse nor on foot. She should estimate the value of the king’s beard or weave a cloth with only a few threads. Or she has to make boiled eggs hatch or carve a fowl & give appropriate pieces to all members of the family. The king marries the girl but orders her not to meddle in his affairs. When he settles a dispute between two farmers unjustly, she advises the wronged man to show the king the absurdity of his decision by an equally foolish act. When the king casts her out & allows her only to take with her the one thing she holds dearest, she takes her sleeping husband with her & thus moves him to forgive.

When Weinsberg is besieged, the king per-mits the women to leave & to take with them whatever they can carry (whatever is dearest to them). Each woman carries her (sleeping, drunken) husband out of the city. When the sol diers see what is happening, they try to prevent it. They appeal to the king. He appreciates the women’s clever plan & declares that his promise to the women must be kept.

Classifications: Girl's Riddling Answer Betrays a Thief
Variation Example: A prince sends his servant to a clever girl with a round tart, thirty cakes, & a capon, & asks the girl if it is the full moon, if it is the thirtieth of the month, & if the rooster has crowed in the evening. She replies that it is not full moon, that it is the fifteenth of the month & that the rooster has gone to the mill; but that the prince should spare the pheasant for the partridge’s sake. She thus shows him that the servant has stolen half the tart, half of the cakes, & the capon.

The contents & combinations of the impossible tasks & their countertasks vary in the numerous variants of this type, where a person imposes an impossible task on someone who, in return, imposes an equally absurd countertask. (1) A prince (king) makes an impossible demand: Three unwed girls (virgins) should all give birth to a child at the same time (within nine months). Being summoned to the palace they present themselves disguised as pregnant women by hiding cushions under their dresses. When they are granted a wish, the youngest sister asks for roasted snow. Being unable to produce it, the prince realizes the absurdity of his own demand & marries the girl. (2) A king imprisons an adviser & will release him only on the condition that he brings a horse that is neither black nor white, neither gray nor reddish brown. The adviser claims to have such a horse at home, but the king cannot fetch it on any day of the week. The king sees the absurdity of his own demand & releases his prisoner. (3) A prince finds a block of white marble so beautiful that he orders his tailor to sew him a suit out of the stone. No tailor in the kingdom can do this & he orders them all to be killed. Finally an elderly tailor is asked to make the suit. On the advice of his granddaughter he asks the prince for meat made of mud & a cake of snow for lunch. Thus he points to his master’s own absurd task, whereupon the prince recognizes his mistake & marries the granddaughter. (4) A king orders his adviser (boy) to bring him bull’s milk or to have a bull bear a calf. The adviser’s daughter pretends that her father has given birth to a child & the king thus sees the absurdity of his order. (5) A Muslim king orders his adviser to convert him into a Hindu. The adviser stands by the road rubbing a donkey. When the king asks why, the adviser explains that he is trying to change it into a horse (cow). The king thus sees the absurdity of his order. (6) A king orders his adviser to move a well. On the advice of his daughter, the adviser tells the king that the king must help by send ing him the well. The king thus sees the absurdity of his order. (7) The king asks a farmer for a tribute of calves born to bulls. The farmer’s son replies, “Let me go & ask my father who is guard ing the fields, lets fish come up from the seashore & eat the millet”. (8) Other impossible tasks that occur in some variants are: grow-ing onions out of a stone, winding a rope of chaff, making a rope of sand, counting the leaves of the flowers or the stars in the sky, measuring the sky, sewing a millstone, drying snow on the stove, drying a candle.

Classifications: Storytelling Saves a Wife from Death (Sheherazade)
Variation Example: A king who discovers that his wife is unfaithful has her executed. Then, each night, he takes a new wife & has her killed the following day (after she gives birth). After three years (one year) the vizier is unable to find a suitable woman, so the king condemns him to death. The vizier’s daughter volunteers to marry the king (although her father objects). She tells stories to the king (with the help of her sister, or a courtier tells the stories). The king postpones the execution. After ayear of storytelling (after the wife gives birth), the king realizes that it would be wrong to kill this woman.

Classifications: Clever Young Woman at the End of the Journey
Variation Example: She explains various enigmatic statements & actions encountered by people on the way. Finally she succeeds in a contest in repartee & in performing impossible tasks. A (dried) fish laughs in the palace. The king orders his vizier (a man) on pain of death to find out why (to solve another problem). The vizier (his son) sets out on a journey. He meets an old man & makes various enigmatic suggestions (two men travel together & one makes enigmatic suggestions). “Let us carry one another”, means, “Let us tell stories to shorten the way”. – “Let us get horses in the forest”, means, “Let us cut walking sticks”. Or, one man does seemingly absurd things e.g. he wears his shoes in the streams & carries them on dry land. The man’s daughter correctly interprets the enigmatic remarks or the seemingly absurd actions. Finally the vizier’s son marries the girl because she answers the original question: The fish laughed because there was a man dressed in woman’s clothes in the harem.

A prince goes to seven wise teachers to be educated. When he comes back to the palace he pretends to be mute (on the advice of his teachers). The prince’s stepmother makes advances to her stepson, & then accuses him to his father who condemns the prince to death. The seven wise men & the queen argue the case by telling stories for seven days. In some variants the prince (on advice of his tutors) proves to his father, that one of the queen’s maidservants is a man dressed as a woman. The queen & her lover are hanged (and the prince’s innocence is proved).

Classifications: The Unjust Decision: The Oil Press Gives Birth to a Foal
Variation Example: A traveler ties his mare to an oilman’s mill. During the night the mare gives birth to a foal. The oilman claims it, saying the mill (vehicle, pale, crutch ed stick) has given birth to the foal. Or, a rich neighbor claims a calf (from his poor neighbor, who owns the cow) saying that his ox had given birth to it. The judge (jackal) has to decide the case. He arrives late, explaining that the sea was burning & that he had to put the fire out with straw (other absurd explanations). Thus the absurdity of the oilman’s claim becomes clear (and the traveler may keep the foal).

Classifications: The Old Woman who was Skinned
Variation Example: An ugly old maid succeeds in marrying her old & ugly sister to a king (prince) who wants to marry a young woman. In order to hide the ugliness of his bride, she shows the prince only her fingers through the keyhole & the sound of her voice. On the wedding night he discovers the deception & throws the bride out of the window where she is caught in a tree. Some fairies observe this & laugh at the dangling old woman. The fairies, grateful for the amusement they have had, recompense the old woman by rejuvenating her into a beautiful girl. The king marries her. Being jealous of her sister’s fortune, the other old maid asks her how she became young. The latter, fearing another ruse of her sister’s, explains that she has been skinned. She advises her sister have a barber skin her (the sister has herself skinned & dies).

A prince (young man) passing by asks a girl who is watering her basil plant (ridiculing her) how many leaves her plant has. The girl answers with a counter question: How many stars does the sky have?. The prince does not know the answer & continues on his way ashamed. The next day he returns masked as a merchant (fisherman) & sells something precious to the girl in return for a kiss. Or, the prince repeatedly pricks the girl with a needle; she com-plains of insect bites. The next day the prince mocks the girl or reveals the deceit (the kiss & the pricking) to her. Next the girl disguises herself as a doctor (death, angel of death), pays a visit to the prince who is feeling sick, & mistreats (mocks) him or makes him believe that death has come to him. Disguised as merchant the girl sells something to the prince on the condition that he kisses his donkey under the tail (his horse’s leg). The prince marries the girl, intending to avenge himself by killing her on the wedding night. But she puts a life-sized doll made of sugar (syrup) in her place & hides herself under the bed. When the prince destroys the doll with a sword-thrust & accidentally tastes its sweet “blood”, he regrets his deed. (The girl comes out of her hiding place & they are reconciled to one another.)

A king in disguise overhears three (two) (poor) girls expressing their wishes. The youngest declares that even if the king would like to marry her, he would have to serve her first. The king fulfills the wishes of the elder ones & punishes (imprisons, condemns to death) the youngest. The clever girl escapes (is saved) and/or finds a treasure (and builds a castle). Dressed in new clothes she makes the king fall in love & serve her. She discloses her identity & they marry.

A princess falls in love with a very beautiful fisherman’s son & wants to marry him. The boy, worried about his low social standing, warns her that if she ever reproaches him for his social status, he will never talk again. On the wedding night the princess mocks him for his clumsy manners. He leaves her immediately & takes employment at the king’s court. The king, impressed by his beauty, regrets that he cannot speak & promises a reward to whoever succeeds in making him talk again; failure will be punished by death. The princess comes disguised as a man (doctor). For three nights she tries in vain to cure him & is finally led to the gallows. The boy (her husband), who is one of the spectators at her exe cution, speaks to her (in a very degrading way) at the very last mo ment & so saves her life.

Classifications: The Man Boasts of his Wife
Variation Example: A man boasts of the cleverness of his wife at a king’s court. He is imprisoned (in the royal castle) in order to test whether his wife is able to find & to free him. When she learns about his imprisonment, she disguises herself as a man & comes to live at the court. The princess falls in love with her & their marriage is planned. When her masculinity is doubted she has to undergo ordeals to prove her sex, but passes them all. Finally she manages to free her husband by a trick (ex change of clothes) & escapes with him.

A soldier beats his general at gambling & then marries the general’s daughter. Later, he loses all his money at gambling, & returns to his poor parents. His wife wins back what he had lost & finds her husband.

A merchant marries (falls in love with) a woman (princess) of high descent (extraordinary beauty). During the absence of her husband (on a journey), another man (relative, several men) tries to seduce her but is rejected. The man slanders her to her husband. He believes the false evidence that she was unfaithful during his absence & orders that she be killed. She asks to be left in a box in the sea, & escapes. A doctor (another man) heals her & wants to marry her (she is found by other men who all want to marry her). Through her cleverness she eludes or escapes from all the men who (fall in love with her and) want to possess her. After these adventures she disguises herself as a man & becomes king. She has her picture (painting, photo, statue) displayed in a public place (a personal report is published, her life-story is written on a vault). Every person who comments on the picture is imprisoned. All the men she had known during her life, her husband included, come (to the picture) & describe their meeting with her. The woman in man’s clothes condemns, pardons, or recompenses them according to the roles they played in her life. Finally she discloses her identity & is reunited with (marries) her husband. (She changes roles with her husband so that he becomes ruler.)

Classifications: The Abandoned Bride Disguised as a Man
Variation Example: A prince & his bride are separated in a forest. She escapes from her would-be seducers. (She shoots an arrow, saying she will marry the one who first re turns with it, & escapes while the men pursue the arrow.) The bride disguises herself as a man & is chosen king (given other high honors in a strange land). Or she dis-guises herself as a servant to the king & overpowers an ogress. (She hears a cry at night & finds an ogress trying to devour a human corpse. She cuts off the ogress’s leg or the like & is rewarded by the king.) She “marries” a princess (princesses). She displays her picture (statue) in a public place & posts servants (stays there herself) to overhear comments. She gives alms to all comers. In this way she finds her husband. The would-be seducers are punished.

Classifications: The Wager on the Wife's Chastity (Cymbeline)
Variation Example: (Cymbeline.) A husband (ship captain) praises the virtue of his wife (poor girl) & makes a wager with a friend (business partner, merchant, adversary) regarding her chastity. After trying in vain to seduce the woman, the friend, with the help of a corrupt servant, secretly goes into her bedroom (hidden in a box). There, without touching her, he discovers a birthmark on her breast and/or secures a token (ring or clothing) & uses it to pretend that he seduced her. The hus band believes him, casts off his wife (orders someone to kill her), & leaves home. The woman escapes death & travels in man’s clothes. She gains a high position at a foreign court. There she meets her husband, who has become destitute & proves her innocence to him. In some variants she follows her husband & serves him un-recognized (in man’s clothes) for several years. Finally the slanderer is unmasked & the couple is reunited.
In the absence of her husband (ship captain) a wife is annoyed by three suitors. She tricks them into a room & makes them spin (work).

In the absence of her father (parents), a relative (friend, clergyman, guardian) attempts to seduce a young woman. When she rejects him, he writes a slanderous letter (out of revenge) to her father accusing her of loose conduct. The father commands his son to kill his sister. Out of pity (believing in her innocence) the brother spares her & gives the liver (heart, blood) of an animal to the king as proof of the murder. The girl is abandoned. A king (prince) finds her & marries her. When the king has to go to war (when the woman with her children wants to pay a visit to her father), he tells a servant (officer, soldier, dignitary) or a relative (brother, uncle) to take care of (accompany) his wife. A second attempt at seduction is made, & the woman’s children are often killed. She escapes in man’s clothes (dis-guised as soldier, officer or shepherd) & works unre cog-nized as a servant in her father’s house (in an inn, as a shepherd). Despite the slanderer’s statement that the queen is dead (abducted, escaped, has murdered her children), the king searches for his wife (father searches for his daughter). Finally all persons concerned meet together & the woman in man’s clothes tells them what had happened (in the form of a tale). The family is reunited & the evildoers are punished.

Before going on a journey, a man (merchant) locks up his three daughters, & gives each of them a magic object (ring, flowers) that will indicate if they are un-chaste. A prince (knight, three princes, three young men) enters the girls’ room secretly (disguised as a merchant) & seduces the two elder ones. The clever youngest sister resists his attempt at seduction & teases the prince. When her sisters have given birth, she dis-guises herself as a beggar & carries the newborn children to the princes’ castle (to their fathers). When the merchant comes home & realizes what has happened, he intends to kill the two sisters. (But when the princes agree to marry his daughters he abandons his plan). The prince who wants to marry his youngest daughter plans to kill her on her wedding night. She puts a sugar doll in her place. He cuts the doll with his sword, & when he tastes the “blood” he realizes “the sweetness” of his wife & regrets his deed. (The girl shows up & they are reconciled with one another.)

A maiden is cast out from home, marries a man of the lower class, & has three sons whom she names “‘What was I?”, “What am I?” & “What will I be?” (the like). In this way she attracts her father’s attention, & becomes reconciled with him.

Classifications: The Forsaken Fiancee: Service as Menial
Variation Example: This misc. type comprises various tales with different contents. The variants include different combinations of the following motifs: A woman disguised in man’s clothes, test of a person’s gender, separation of lovers (couple), wife finds lost husband as he is about to marry another, girl in menial disguise at lover’s court, the forgotten fiancée recognition of lover through displaying a picture, & the prince marries his first fiancée.
